title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) — History arrived not with a whisper, but with a thunderous, earth-shaking slam that rattled the very foundations of KeyArena. On a night the final score read 103-84 in favor of the Seattle SuperSonics, the numbers that truly mattered were 41, 17, and 5. They belonged to Shawn Kemp, who delivered a performance of raw, unadulterated power that transcended the game itself.

From the opening tip, Kemp was a force of nature, an unstoppable storm of athleticism and fury. The Dallas Mavericks had no answer. Double-teams were brushed aside. Contested shots were met with a higher, more violent trajectory. Kemp didn’t just score; he imposed his will, dominating the painted area with a series of ferocious dunks that brought the Seattle faithful to a fever pitch with each descent through the net.

His 41 points were a career-high, a masterpiece of inside dominance. But the carnage didn’t stop there. He ripped down 17 rebounds, a Herculean effort on the glass that choked the life out of any potential Dallas rally. He was not just the offense; he was the defense, the energy, the very heartbeat of the Sonics’ commanding victory.

While Gary Payton provided a steady, All-Star hand with 22 points and 10 assists, this was Kemp’s canvas, and he painted it with broad, powerful strokes. The Mavericks, led by Jim Jackson’s 18 points, were merely spectators to a personal showcase of greatness.

In the end, the Sonics’ 19-point win was almost a footnote. The real story was the man they called "The Reign Man," who for one legendary night in 1997, didn’t just reign over the game—he conquered it, leaving a stat line for the ages and an indelible mark on NBA lore.
